results.title: The Field
results.creator_credit: Jim Sheridan, Noel Pearson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: Bull McCabe (Richard Harris) and his son Tadgh (Sean Bean) have sacrificed their lives for the sake of turning the land of a local widower into a successful field but when she says she wants to sell to the highest bidder at public auction, there is no guarantee that the McCabe’s history with the land will guarantee future ownership. Bull’s biggest fear that the field will be taken over by an outsider becomes a reality when “The American” (Tom Berenger) arrives in their small Irish town. Without any cash or other means at their disposal, the only resistance the McCabes can offer is violence, continuing a trend of tragedy that has dogged the family for years. Brenda Fricker co-stars as Bull’s silent and long suffering wife, John Hurt as the simpleton “Bird”. Set in Ireland in the 1930s and based on the play “The Field” by John B. Keane.

results.title: American cinema
results.creator_credit: Greg Martinelli, Molly Ornati, Rita Mate, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description: A 13 part series examining the cinema industry. Producers, directors, actors, cinematographers and Hollywood stars reveal insights into the business of making motion pictures. John Lithgow introduces each episode which encompasses a theme and examines it in detail with clips from some of the world’s renown films.

results.title: The Ferrara poems
results.creator_credit: Jenny Robertson, S A Department for the Arts and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Two Australian travellers Karl (Michael Snelling) and Giselle (Kerin Murray) meet up with friends at a cafe in Italy for coffee and discuss their cultural experiences and observations of the country. A trip is planned and the group sets off together on another sight-seeing adventure. A postmodernist film essay exploring the structure of storytelling through the deliberate raw use of cinematic and film making devices (making those devices transparent). A film about foreigners, film making and foreign processes. Cast also includes: Ken Bolton, Mark Thomson and Tish Banks. Narrator: Richard Grayson.
